column1: What is the subject of linear systems theory?
column2: The study of systems whose behavior depends linearly on inputs, initial conditions, and internal variables.
column3: Kailath frames this as a mathematical theory, not tied to a specific physical domain.

column1: What distinguishes a system from a signal?
column2: A signal is a function of an independent variable; a system is a mapping from input signals to output signals.

column1: What does it mean to model a system?
column2: To replace a real process by a mathematical description that captures behavior of interest.
Because different models can represent the same physical system depending on objectives.

column1: What is meant by linearity of a system?
column2: Superposition holds: responses to summed or scaled inputs equal summed or scaled responses.
column3: Assumed with respect to chosen variables.

column2: System behavior is unchanged by shifts of the time origin.

column1: Why does Kailath emphasize structure over solution formulas?
column2: Because structural properties persist under transformations and generalize across problems.
A representation describes behavior; a realization specifies internal structure.

column1: Why is equivalence of models important?
column2: Different mathematical forms can represent the same system behavior.
column3: Leads to invariants and canonical forms.

column1: ⚠️ Why is it dangerous to confuse a model with the system itself?
column2: Because models are approximations tailored to specific questions.
